Welcome to Post-manager API documentation!¶

Post-manager main¶

This module contains the main FastAPI application for the RestAPI post manager app.

It includes the necessary routes and services to handle authentication, user management, post management, and comment management.

The module also defines a lifespan function that initializes and closes resources, such as a Redis connection and a comment pool. The lifespan function is used by the FastAPI application to manage the lifecycle of these resources.

The module also defines a root route handler that returns a welcome message when the application is accessed.

To run the application, execute this module directly.

Example:

python main.py

main.lifespan(app: FastAPI)¶

The lifespan function is a coroutine that runs before and after the application. It’s used to initialize and close resources, such as redis connection, etc.

Parameters:

app – Pass the fastapi instance to the function

Returns:

An object that can be used to clean up the resources when the server shuts down

async main.read_root()¶

The read_root function returns a dictionary with the key ‘message’ and value ‘Welcome to RestAPI post manager app’.

Returns:

A dictionary

Post-manager repository Comments¶

The comments module contains functions to interact with the comments table in the database.

async src.repository.comments.create_comment(body: CommentCreate, user: User, db: Session, background_tasks: BackgroundTasks) → Comment¶

The create_comment function creates a new comment for a post.

Parameters:

  • body – The comment data

  • db – The database session

Returns:

The created comment

async src.repository.comments.delete_comment(comment_id: int, user: User, db: Session) → dict¶

The delete_comment function deletes a comment.

Parameters:

  • comment_id – The comment id

  • user – The current user

  • db – The database session

Returns:

The deleted comment

async src.repository.comments.get_comment_by_id(comment_id: int, user: User, db: Session) → Comment¶

The get_comment_by_id function return a comment by its id. And if the user is not an admin, it will return only the comments that are not blocked.

Parameters:

  • comment_id – The comment id

  • user – The current user

  • db – The database session

Returns:

The comment

async src.repository.comments.get_comments(user: User, db: Session) → list[Comment]¶

The get_comments function return all comments from current user.

Parameters:

  • user – The current user

  • db – The database session

Returns:

The list of comments

async src.repository.comments.get_comments_daily_breakdown(post_id: int, date_from: str, date_to: str, user: User, db: Session)¶

The get_comments_daily_breakdown function will return analytics aggregated by day for each day. It will return the number of comments created and the number of comments blocked. If the user is not the author or admin, the function will return an exception

Parameters:

  • post_id – The post id

  • date_from – The start date

  • date_to – The end date

  • db – The database session

Returns:

The list of comments

async src.repository.comments.get_comments_for_post(post_id: int, user: User, db: Session) → list[Comment]¶

The get_comments_for_post function return all comments for a post. And if the user is not an admin or an author, it will return only the comments that are not blocked.

Parameters:

  • post_id – The post id

  • user – The current user

  • db – The database session

Returns:

The list of comments

async src.repository.comments.get_comments_for_user(user_id: int, user: User, db: Session) → list[Comment]¶

The get_comments_for_user function return all comments from a user. And if the user is not an admin or an author, it will return only the comments that are not blocked.

Parameters:

  • user_id – The user id

  • user – The current user

  • db – The database session

Returns:

The list of comments

The update_comment function updates a comment.

  • body – The comment data

  • user – The current user

  • db – The database session

Returns:

The updated comment

Post-manager repository Posts¶

This module contains functions for interacting with the posts table in the database.

async src.repository.posts.create_post(body: PostBase, user: User, db: Session) → Post¶

The create_post function creates a new post in the database.

Parameters:

  • body – The post data to create

  • user – The user creating the post

  • db – The database session

Returns:

The created post

async src.repository.posts.delete_post(post_id: int, user: User, db: Session) → dict¶

The delete_post function deletes a post based on the post_id and user_id.

Parameters:

  • post_id – The ID of the post to delete

  • user – The user making the request

  • db – The database session

Returns:

A message indicating the success of the operation

async src.repository.posts.get_post_by_id(post_id: int, db: Session, user: User = None) → Post¶

The get_post_by_id function returns a post based on the post_id and user_id. Parameter user is optional and is used to check if the post belongs to the user if function is called from update_post or delete_post.

Parameters:

  • post_id – The ID of the post to return

  • user – The user making the request

  • db – The database session

Returns:

The post with the specified ID

async src.repository.posts.get_posts(limit: int, offset: int, descending: bool, db: Session) → list[Post]¶

The get_posts function returns a list of posts based on the limit and offset provided. The posts can be sorted in ascending or descending order.

Parameters:

  • limit – The number of posts to return

  • offset – The number of posts to skip from the start

  • descending – Sort the posts in descending order

  • db – The database session

Returns:

A list of posts

async src.repository.posts.get_posts_from_user(username: str, limit: int, offset: int, descending: bool, db: Session) → list[Post]¶

The get_posts_from_user function returns a list of posts from a user.

Parameters:

  • username – The username of the user to get posts from

  • limit – The number of posts to return

  • offset – The number of posts to skip from the start

  • descending – Sort the posts in descending order

  • db – The database session

Returns:

A list of posts from the specified user

async src.repository.posts.search_posts(text: str | None, author: str | None, db: Session) → list[Post]¶

The search_posts function searches for posts based on the text or author. If both text and author are provided, the search is performed on both fields.

Parameters:

  • text – Search by text

  • author – Search by author

  • db – The database session

Returns:

A list of posts matching the search criteria

async src.repository.posts.update_post(post_id: int, body: PostBase, user: User, db: Session) → Post¶

The update_post function updates a post based on the post_id and user_id.

Parameters:

  • post_id – The ID of the post to update

  • body – The post data to update

  • user – The user making the request

  • db – The database session

Returns:

The updated post

Post-manager routes Auth¶

This module contains the API routes related to user authentication.

It includes the following routes: - /auth/signup: Creates a new user in the database. - /auth/login: Authenticates a user and returns an access token. - /auth/refresh-token: Refreshes the access token. - /auth/confirm-email/{token}: Confirms a user’s email address. - /auth/request-email: Sends an email to the user with a link to confirm their account.

async src.routes.auth.confirm_email(token: str, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The confirm_email function is used to confirm a user’s email address.

Parameters:

  • token – Get the token from the url

  • db – Get the database connection

Returns:

A dictionary with message ‘Your email is already confirmed’ or ‘Email confirmed’

async src.routes.auth.login(body: OAuth2PasswordRequestForm = Depends(NoneType), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The login function is used to authenticate a user. It takes in the email and password of the user, and returns an access token if successful.

Parameters:

  • body – Get the email and password from the request body

  • db – Access the database

Returns:

A dictionary with the following keys:

async src.routes.auth.refresh_token(credentials: HTTPAuthorizationCredentials = Security(HTTPBearer), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The refresh_token function is used to refresh the access token. It takes in a refresh token and returns an access_token, a new refresh_token, and the type of token (bearer).

Parameters:

  • credentials – Get the token from the request header

  • db – Get the database session

Returns:

A dictionary with the access_token, refresh_token and token_type

async src.routes.auth.request_email(body: RequestEmail, background_tasks: BackgroundTasks, request: Request, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The request_email function is used to send an email to the user with a link to confirm their account.

The function takes in the body of the request, which contains only one field: email. It then uses this information to query for a user in our database and if it finds one, sends them an email with a link that they can use to confirm their account.

Parameters:

  • body – Validate the request body

  • background_tasks – Add a task to the background queue

  • request – Get the base_url of the application

  • db – Create a database session

Returns:

A dictionary with a message ‘Check your email for confirmation’ or ‘Your email already confirmed’

async src.routes.auth.signup(body: UserModel, background_tasks: BackgroundTasks, request: Request, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The signup function creates a new user in the database.

Parameters:

  • body – Get the data from the request body

  • background_tasks – Add a task to the background tasks queue

  • request – Get the base url of the server

  • db – Pass the database session to the repository

Returns:

A dictionary

Post-manager routes Comments¶

This module contains the API routes for managing comments.

Endpoints: - POST /comments: Create a new comment for a post. - GET /comments: Get all comments from the current user. - GET /comments/{comment_id}: Get a comment by its ID. - GET /comments/for-user/{user_id}: Get all comments for a user. - GET /comments/for-post/{post_id}: Get all comments for a post. - GET /comments/daily-breakdown/{post_id}: Get statistic based on blocked and not blocked comments for a post within a date range. - PATCH /comments/{comment_id}: Update a comment. - DELETE /comments/{comment_id}: Delete a comment.

async src.routes.comments.create_comment(body: CommentCreate, background_tasks: BackgroundTasks, curr_user: User = Depends(get_current_user), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

  • db – The database session

Returns:

The created comment

The get_comments_daily_breakdown function return all comments for a post within a date range. It will return analytics aggregated by day, for each day, the number of comments created and the number of comments blocked

Parameters:

Post-manager routes Posts¶

This module contains the API routes for managing posts.

Routes: - POST /posts: Create a new post. - GET /posts: Get a list of posts based on the provided parameters. - GET /posts/{post_id}: Get a post by its ID. - GET /posts/{username}: Get a list of posts from a specific user. - GET /posts/search: Search for posts based on text or author. - PATCH /posts/{post_id}: Update a post by its ID. - DELETE /posts/{post_id}: Delete a post by its ID.

async src.routes.posts.create_post(body: PostBase, curr_user: User = Depends(get_current_user), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The create_post function creates a new post in the database.

Parameters:

  • curr_user – The current user making the request

  • db – The database session

Returns:

The created post

The delete_post function deletes a post by its ID.

Parameters:

  • post_id – The ID of the post to delete

  • curr_user – The current user making the request

  • db – The database session

Returns:

None

async src.routes.posts.get_post_by_id(post_id: int, curr_user: User = Depends(get_current_user), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The post with the specified ID

The get_posts function returns a list of posts based on the limit and offset provided. The posts can be sorted in ascending or descending order.

Parameters:

  • curr_user – The current user making the request

  • db – The database session

A list of posts

Post-manager routes Users¶

This module contains the API routes related to user operations.

It defines the following routes: - GET /users/me: Returns the current user’s information. - POST /users/auto-response: Sets the auto response status for the current user. - DELETE /users/me/delete: Deletes the current user’s account.

async src.routes.users.auto_response(response: bool = Query(False), response_interval: int = Query(300), curr_user: User = Depends(get_current_user), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

  • db – Get the database session

The current user

Parameters:

curr_user – Get the current user

Returns:

Post-manager services Auth¶

This module contains the Auth class, which is used for authentication-related operations such as hashing passwords, creating and verifying tokens, and retrieving user information.

The Auth class provides the following methods: - verify_password(plain_password, hashed_password): Verifies if a plain-text password matches a hashed password. - get_password_hash(password): Returns the hash of a given password. - create_token(username, delta, scope): Creates a JWT token with the specified payload. - create_access_token(username): Creates a new access token for a user. - create_refresh_token(username): Creates a refresh token for a user. - create_email_token(email): Creates a token for a given email address. - decode_refresh_token(refresh_token): Decodes a refresh token and returns the associated email address. - get_current_user(token, db): Retrieves the current user based on the provided token and database session. - get_email_from_token(token): Retrieves the email address associated with a given token.

class src.services.auth.Auth¶

Bases: object

The Auth class is used to hash passwords, create tokens, and verify tokens.

ALGORITHM = 'HS256'¶
SECRET_KEY = 'fM4pJvK5s2vY9rB1qX4cU7zW0pS3lN6f'¶

async create_email_token(email: str)¶

The create_email_token function creates a token for the given email. The token is valid for 7 days and has the ‘email_scope’ scope.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • email – Specify the email address of the user

Returns:

A token

Parameters:

  • username – Create a refresh token for the user

Returns:

A refresh token that expires in 7 days

async get_current_user(token: str = Depends(OAuth2PasswordBearer), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The get_current_user function is a dependency that will be used in the

Parameters:

  • token – Get the token from the authorization header

  • db – Pass the database session to the function

Raises:

credentials_exception – If the credentials are invalid

Returns:

The user object

async get_email_from_token(token: str)¶

The get_email_from_token function takes a token as an argument and returns the email address associated with that token. The function first decodes the JWT using our SECRET_KEY and ALGORITHM, then checks to make sure that the scope is correct. If it is not, we raise an HTTPException with status code 401 (Unauthorized) and detail message ‘Invalid scope for token’. If everything goes well, we return payload[‘sub’], which contains the email address.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • token – Pass the token to the function

Returns:

The email address from the token

get_password_hash(password: str)¶

The get_password_hash function takes a password as input and returns the hash of that password.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • password – Get the password from the user

Returns:

A hash of the password

oauth2_scheme = <fastapi.security.oauth2.OAuth2PasswordBearer object>¶
pwd_context = <CryptContext>¶
verify_password(plain_password: str, hashed_password: str)¶

The verify_password function takes a plain-text password and a hashed password, and returns True if the plain-text password matches the hashed

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • plain_password – Pass in the plain text password that the user has entered

  • hashed_password – Pass in the hashed password from the database

Returns:

True if the password is correct and False otherwise

Post-manager services Email¶

This module provides functionality for sending emails using FastAPI-Mail.

It contains the send_email function which sends an email to the user with a link to verify their account.

async src.services.email.send_email(email: EmailStr, username: str, host: str)¶

The send_email function sends an email to the user with a link to verify their account.

Parameters:

  • email – Pass the email address to send the email to

  • username – Pass the username of the user to be sent an email

  • host – Pass the host name of the server to the email template

Returns:

A coroutine object

Post-manager services AI_Services¶

This module contains services related to AI moderation and comment response.

It provides the following classes and functions: - moderate_content: A function that moderates the content of a comment or post. - comment_response: A function that generates a response to a comment. - CommentPool: A class that represents a pool of comments to be processed.

The module also defines dictionaries for moderate content handlers and response handlers, which map AI names to their corresponding moderation and response functions.

class src.services.ai_services.CommentPool¶

Bases: object

The CommentPool class is a pool of comments that need to be processed.

async add_comment(comment, post, interval: int, response_func: Callable)¶

The add_comment function adds a comment to the pool.

async process_comments()¶

The process_comments function processes the comments in the pool.

async start()¶

The start function starts the comment pool.

async stop()¶

The stop function stops the comment pool.

The comment_response function generates a response to a comment.

Parameters:

item – The comment

Returns:

The response

The moderate_content function moderates the content of a comment.

Parameters:

  • text – The text of the comment

  • user – The current

  • db – The database session

Returns:

The moderation result

Post-manager services AI Claude_ai¶

This module contains functions for content moderation and generating responses using Claude AI.

The module includes the following functions: - check_content: Analyzes the given item for inappropriate content using Claude AI. - moderate_content: Moderates the content of a post or comment item with Claude AI. - comment_response: Generates a response for the given comment with Claude AI.

async src.services.ai.claude_ai.check_content(item) → dict¶

Analyzes the given item for inappropriate content using Claude AI. The return dictionary has the following keys: - “is_acceptable”: A boolean value indicating whether the content is acceptable or not. - “explanation”: A short explanation justifying the decision.

Parameters:

item – The item to be analyzed. It can be either a PostAiModel or a CommentAiModel.

Returns:

A dictionary containing the analysis result.

Raises:

HTTPException If there is an error in content moderation.

async src.services.ai.claude_ai.comment_response(item: CommentAiModel) → dict¶

Generates a response for the given comment with Claude AI.

Parameters:

item – The comment item to generate a response for.

Returns:

A dictionary containing the generated response.

Raises:

HTTPException if there is an error in generating the response.

async src.services.ai.claude_ai.moderate_content(item: PostAiModel | CommentAiModel) → dict¶

Moderates the content of a post or comment item with Claude AI.

Parameters:

item – The post or comment item to be moderated.

Return dict:

The result of the content moderation.

Raises:

HTTPException If there is an HTTP exception or unexpected error during the moderation process.

Post-manager services AI Gemini_ai¶

This module contains functions for content moderation and generating responses using the Gemini AI model.

The module includes the following functions: - check_content: Analyzes the given item for inappropriate content. - moderate_content: Moderates the content of a post or comment item with Gemini AI. - comment_response: Generates a response for the given comment with Gemini AI.

async src.services.ai.gemini_ai.check_content(item) → dict¶

Analyzes the given item for inappropriate content. The return dictionary has the following keys: - “is_acceptable”: A boolean value indicating whether the content is acceptable or not. - “explanation”: A short explanation justifying the decision.

Parameters:

item – The item to be analyzed. It can be either a PostAiModel or a CommentAiModel.

Returns:

A dictionary containing the analysis result.

Raises:

HTTPException If there is an error in content moderation.

async src.services.ai.gemini_ai.comment_response(item: CommentAiModel) → dict¶

Generates a response for the given comment with gemini ai.

Parameters:

item – The comment item to generate a response for.

Returns:

A dictionary containing the generated response.

Raises:

HTTPException if there is an error in generating the response.

async src.services.ai.gemini_ai.moderate_content(item: PostAiModel | CommentAiModel) → dict¶

Moderates the content of a post or comment item with gemini ai.

Parameters:

item – The post or comment item to be moderated.

Return dict:

The result of the content moderation.

Reises:

HTTPException If there is an HTTP exception or unexpected error during the moderation process.

Post-manager services AI GPT_or_LLAMA_ai¶

This module contains functions for content moderation and generating responses using OpenAI’s GPT-3 model.

Functions: - check_content(item) -> dict: Analyzes the given item for inappropriate content using OpenAI. - moderate_content(item) -> dict: Moderates the content of a post or comment item with OpenAI. - comment_response(item) -> dict: Generates a response for the given comment with OpenAI.

async src.services.ai.gpt_or_llama_ai.check_content(item) → dict¶

Analyzes the given item for inappropriate content using OpenAI. The return dictionary has the following keys: - “is_acceptable”: A boolean value indicating whether the content is acceptable or not. - “explanation”: A short explanation justifying the decision.

Parameters:

item – The item to be analyzed. It can be either a PostAiModel or a CommentAiModel.

Returns:

A dictionary containing the analysis result.

Raises:

HTTPException If there is an error in content moderation.

async src.services.ai.gpt_or_llama_ai.comment_response(item: CommentAiModel) → dict¶

Generates a response for the given comment with OpenAI.

Parameters:

item – The comment item to generate a response for.

Returns:

A dictionary containing the generated response.

Raises:

HTTPException if there is an error in generating the response.

async src.services.ai.gpt_or_llama_ai.moderate_content(item: PostAiModel | CommentAiModel) → dict¶

Moderates the content of a post or comment item with OpenAI.

Parameters:

item – The post or comment item to be moderated.

Return dict:

The result of the content moderation.

Raises:

HTTPException If there is an HTTP exception or unexpected error during the moderation process.

Post-manager database DB¶

This module contains the database connection and session management code.

src.database.db.get_db()¶

The get_db function opens a new database connection if there is none yet for the current application context. It will also create the database tables we need for our models if they don’t exist yet.

Returns:

A database session

Post-manager database Models¶

This module contains the models for the database tables
